greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Largest 3-smooth divisor of n.
comment: Bennett, Filaseta, & Trifonov show that if n > 8 then a(n^2 + n) < n^0.715. - _Charles R Greathouse IV_, May 21 2014
link: Charles R Greathouse IV, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
M. A. Bennett, M. Filaseta, and O. Trifonov, On the factorization of consecutive integers, J. Reine Angew. Math. 629 (2009), pp. 171-200.
formula: Multiplicative with a(2^e)=2^e, a(3^e)=3^e, a(p^e)=1, p>3. - _Vladeta Jovovic_, Nov 05 2001

Sum_{k=1..n} a(k) ~ n*(log(n)^2 + (2*gamma + 3*log(2) + 2*log(3) - 2)*log(n) + (2 + log(2)^2/6 + 3*log(2)*(log(3) - 1) - 2*log(3) + log(3)^2/6 + gamma*(3*log(2) + 2*log(3) - 2) - 2*sg1)) / (6*log(2)*log(3)), where gamma is the Euler-Mascheroni constant A001620 and sg1 is the first Stieltjes constant (see A082633). - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Sep 19 2020
maple: A065331 := proc(n) n/A065330(n) ; end: # _R. J. Mathar_, Jun 24 2009
program: (PARI) a(n)=gcd(n,6^n) \\ Not very efficient, but simple. _Stanislav Sykora_, Feb 08 2016
f p y x | r == 0    = f p (y * p) x'
| otherwise = if p == 2 then f 3 y x else y
results.author: _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Oct 29 2001
